case_name: State of Assam v. Gauhati Municipal Board

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 1268 of 1966 is an appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated May 21, 1965 of the Assam and Nagaland High Court in Civil Rule No. 306 of 1964.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 1268 of 1966. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated May 21, 1965 of the Assam and Nagaland High Court in Civil Rule No. 306 of 1964.

facts.text: The appellant is the State of Assam and the respondent is the Gauhati Municipal Board.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is the State of Assam and the respondent is the Gauhati Municipal Board,  hereinafter referred to as the Board .

facts.text: New members of the Board began to function from July 7, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: After the municipal election, new members of the Board began to function from July 7, 1962.

facts.text: The term of the members is four years and would normally have expired on July 6, 1966.

anchor.surface_text: The term of the members is four years and would in the numbermal companyrse have expired on July 6, 1966.

facts.text: On June 9, 1964, the appellant issued notice to the Board under s. 298 of the Assam Municipal Act, No. XV of 1957.

anchor.surface_text: On June 9, 1964, the appellant issued numberice to the Board under s. 298 of the Assam Municipal Act, No. XV of 1957  hereinafter referred to as the Act .

facts.text: The notice stated that the State Government was of the opinion that the Board was incompetent to perform or had persistently made default in performance of duties or abused its powers.

anchor.surface_text: In this numberice the State Government said that it was of the opinion that the Board was incompetent to perform or had persistently made default in the performance of the duties imposed on it by or under the Act or otherwise by law and that the Board had abused its powers.

facts.text: The notice indicated tentative conclusion that the Board should be superseded under s. 298 and asked to show cause, listing eight charges.

anchor.surface_text: The numberice went on to say that the State Government had companye to the tentative companyclusion that the Board should be superseded under s. 298 of the Act and asked the Board to show cause why this should number be done.

facts.text: The Board gave explanation on August 10, 1964.

anchor.surface_text: The Board gave the explanation on August 10, 1964.

facts.text: On December 9, 1964, the State Government issued notification superseding the Board for one year with effect from December 14, 1964.

anchor.surface_text: on December 9, 1964, the State Government issued the numberification superseding the Board for one year with effect from December 14, 1964 for reasons which were stated in the numberification.

facts.text: The Board filed a writ petition in the High Court on December 24, 1964.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon the Board filed a writ petition in the High Court on December 24, 1964 on various grounds.

facts.text: Writ petition ground i: State Government violated principles of natural justice by denying personal hearing and opportunity to produce evidence, as proceedings were quasi-judicial.

anchor.surface_text: three of the grounds raised therein were  i  that in passing the order of supersession the State Government had violated the prin- ciples of natural justice inasmuch as the Board had been denied the opportunity of being personally heard and of producing evidence, as the proceedings resulting in supersession were quasijudicial proceedings,

facts.text: Writ petition ground ii: Charges found proved in notification of December 9, 1964 were not the same as in notice of June 9, 1964.

anchor.surface_text: ii  that the charges which were found proved in the numberification of December 9, 1964 were number the same which were the subject matter of the numberice of June 9, 1964,

facts.text: Writ petition ground iii: State Government prejudged the issue by concluding in notice of June 9, 1964 that Board should be superseded.

anchor.surface_text: iii  that the State Government had already companye to the companyclusion that the Board should be superseded when it gave numberice of June 9, 1964 and had thus prejudged the issue even before the explanation of the Board had been received.

facts.text: Appellant contended that proceedings under s.298 are administrative, not quasi-judicial.

anchor.surface_text: The application was opposed by the appellant, and its case was that proceedings resulting in an order under s. 298 of the Act were administrative proceedings and number quasi- judicial proceedings.

facts.text: Appellant contended that notice and explanation satisfied natural justice even if quasi-judicial.

anchor.surface_text: In any case even if they were quasi- judicial proceedings, the appellant companytended that it had given a hearing to the Board as required by s. 298 and there was numberviolation of the principles of natural justice.

facts.text: High Court held proceedings under s.298 are quasi-judicial and natural justice violated.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that the proceedings culminating in an order under s. 298 of the Act were quasi-judicial and that there was violation of the principles of natural justice in this case.

facts.text: High Court held charges proved different from charges levelled.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court also held that the charges found proved in the numberification of December 9, 1964 were different from the charges levelled in the numberice June 9, 1964.

facts.text: High Court held State Government prejudged issue in notice.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court finally held that the State Government had already made up its mind to supersede the Board when it issued numberice and therefore presumably all the proceedings subsequent to the issue of the numberice were a farce.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds no violation of natural justice as s.298 complied with and no demand for personal hearing by Board.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore where a provision like s. 298 is fully companyplied with as in this case and the Board does number ask for an opportunity for personal hearing or for production of materials in support of its explanation, principles of natural justice do number require that the State Government should ask the Board to appear for a personal hearing and to produce materials in support of the explanation.

facts.text: Supreme Court finds charges found proved are substantially the same as levelled, just reordered.

anchor.surface_text: We have companypared the numberification of December 9, 1964 with the numberice of June 9, 1964. and find that the first charge found proved in the numberification is the third charge in the numberice the second charge found proved in the numberification is the fifth charge in the numberice the third charge found proved in the numberification is the fourth charge in the numberice the fourth charge found proved in the numberification is the second charge in the numberice the fifth charge found proved in the numberification is the sixth charge in the numberice and the sixth charge found proved in the numberification is the first charge in the numberice.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds no prejudgment as tentative conclusion in notice does not close mind.

anchor.surface_text: Such tentative companyclusion companysicated to the Board does number mean that the State Government is number open to companyviction at all and whatever the explanation it would pass an order in accordance with its tentative companyclusion. There is therefore numberreason to think that all proceedings subsequent to the issue of numberice dated June 9, 1964 were in this case a farce.

facts.text: Respondent secured stay order and continued to function for full four years till July 6, 1966.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that the respondent had secured a stay order and practically companytinued to function for the full period of four years under the companyer of the stay order.

facts.text: Supreme Court allows appeal, sets aside High Court order, dismisses writ petition.

anchor.surface_text: We therefore allow the appeal, set aside the order of the High Court and dismiss the writ petition.
Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated May 21, 1965 of the Assam and Nagaland High Court in Civil Rule No. 306 of 1964.
Thereupon the Board filed a writ petition in the High Court on December 24, 1964 on various grounds.
On June 9, 1964, the appellant issued notice to the Board under s. 298 of the Assam Municipal Act, No. XV of 1957  hereinafter referred to as the Act .

concepts.interpretation: Provides power to State Government to dissolve or supersede a municipal board if of opinion that it is incompetent, persistently defaults in duties, or abuses powers; requires prior notice to board for explanation, consideration thereof, and notification with reasons.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: persistently makes. default in the performance of the duties imposed on it by or under the Act or otherwise by law, or exceeds or abuses its powers,

concepts.unlisted_description: State power to supersede/dissolve municipal boards for incompetence/default/abuse after notice and explanation.

anchor.surface_text: three of the grounds raised therein were  i  that in passing the order of supersession the State Government had violated the prin- ciples of natural justice inasmuch as the Board had been denied the opportunity of being personally heard and of producing evidence, as the proceedings resulting in supersession were quasijudicial proceedings,

concepts.interpretation: No violation where statutory procedure under s.298 fully complied with by issuing notice, receiving and considering explanation, and board made no demand for personal hearing or production of materials.

anchor.surface_text: Such tentative conclusion communicated to the Board does not mean that the State Government is not open to conviction at all and whatever the explanation it would pass an order in accordance with its tentative conclusion. There is therefore no reason to think that all proceedings subsequent to the issue of notice dated June 9, 1964 were in this case a farce.

concepts.interpretation: Tentative conclusion in notice does not amount to prejudgment or closed mind if government remains open to conviction based on explanation.

issues.text: whether the proceedings resulting in an order under s. 298 of the Act are quasi-judicial proceedings or merely administrative proceedings

anchor.surface_text: whether the proceedings resulting in an order under s. 298 of the Act are quasi-judicial proceedings or merely administrative proceedings.

issues.text: whether there was any violation of the principles of natural justice in this case

anchor.surface_text: the question is whether there was any violation of the principles of natural justice in this case. What the section provides is that a notice should be given to the Board by the State Government and its explanation taken before an order under s. 298 is passed.

issues.text: whether s. 298 which merely says that the State Government should give opportunity to the Board for submitting an explanation in regard to the matter envisages production of evidence-oral or documentary-at some later stage by the Board in support of its explanation

anchor.surface_text: Here again it is unnecessary to decide whether s. 298 which merely says that the State Government should give opportunity to the Board for submitting an explanation in regard to the matter envisages production of evidence-oral or documentary-at some later stage by the Board in support of its explanation.

issues.text: whether the charges found proved in the notification were different from the charges levelled in the notice

anchor.surface_text: Then we come to the finding of the High Court that the charges found proved in the notification were different from the charges levelled in the notice. We regret to say that the High Court did not carefully look into the matter.

issues.text: whether the State Government had already come to the conclusion that the Board should be superseded when it gave notice of June 9, 1964 and had thus prejudged the issue even before the explanation of the Board had been received

anchor.surface_text: three of the grounds raised therein were  i  that in passing the order of supersession the State Government had violated the principles of natural justice inasmuch as the Board had been denied the opportunity of being personally heard and of producing evidence, as the proceedings resulting in supersession were quasijudicial proceedings,  ii  that the charges which were found proved in the notification of December 9, 1964 were not the same which were the subject matter of the notice of June 9, 1964, and  iii  that the State Government had already come to the conclusion that the Board should be superseded when it gave notice of June 9, 1964 and had thus prejudged the issue even before the explanation of the Board had been received.

holdings.text: It is not necessary in the present appeal to decide whether the proceedings resulting in an order under s. 298 of the Act are quasi-judicial proceedings or merely administrative proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: It is not necessary in the present appeal to decide whether the proceedings resulting in an order under s. 298 of the Act are quasi-judicial proceedings or merely administrative proceedings.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Unnecessary to classify as decision favorable even assuming quasi-judicial nature.

holdings.text: where a provision like s. 298 is fully complied with as in this case and the Board does not ask for an opportunity for personal hearing or for production of materials in support of its explanation, principles of natural justice do not require that the State Government should ask the Board to appear for a personal hearing and to produce materials in support of the explanation.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore where a provision like s. 298 is fully complied with as in this case and the Board does not ask for an opportunity for personal hearing or for production of materials in support of its explanation, principles of natural justice do

holdings.reasoning_summary: Full compliance with s.298 procedure and absence of demand for personal hearing or evidence satisfies natural justice even assuming quasi-judicial proceedings.

holdings.text: Here again it is unnecessary to decide whether s. 298 which merely says that the State Government should give opportunity to the Board for submitting an explanation in regard to the matter envisages production of evidence-oral or documentary-at some later stage by the Board in support of its explanation.

anchor.surface_text: Here again it is unnecessary to decide whether s. 298 which merely says that the State Government should give opportunity to the Board for submitting an explanation in regard to the matter envisages production of evidence-oral or documentary-at some later stage by the Board in support of its explanation.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Issue avoided as statutory compliance suffices without need for evidence production.

holdings.text: though there was a change in the order in which charges were enumerated, the charges found proved were substantially the same as the charges levelled.

anchor.surface_text: it will thus be seen that though there was a change in the order in which charges were enumerated, the charges found proved were substantially the same as the charges levelled. We have already indicated that the seventh and eighth charges in the notice were really no charges and were mere inferences and that is why we find no mention of them in the notification.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct comparison of notice and notification shows six charges identical but reordered; seventh/eighth mere inferences.

holdings.text: Such tentative conclusion communicated to the Board does not mean that the State Government is not open to conviction at all and whatever the explanation it would pass an order in accordance with its tentative conclusion. There is therefore no reason to think that all proceedings subsequent to the issue of notice dated June 9, 1964 were in this case a farce.

anchor.surface_text: Such tentative conclusion communicated to the Board does not mean that the State Government is not open to conviction at all and whatever the explanation it would pass an order in accordance with its tentative conclusion. There is therefore no reason to think that all proceedings subsequent to the issue of notice dated June 9, 1964 were in this case a farce.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Tentative conclusion in notice permissible as mind remains open to explanation; no evidence of bias.

holdings.text: it is not correct to use the analogy of Art. 311 for the purpose of s. 298 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that it is not correct to use the analogy of Art. 311 for the purpose of s. 298 of the Act. The issue of two notices under Art. 311 is a very special procedure depending upon the language of that Article. We find no comparable words in s. 298.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Art.311 requires specific two-notice procedure absent in s.298; textual difference precludes analogy.

edges.explanation: Holding unnecessary to decide addresses the evidence production issue

anchor.surface_text: Here again it is unnecessary to decide whether s. 298 which merely says that the State Government should give opportunity to the Board for submitting an explanation in regard to the matter envisages production of evidence-oral or documentary-at some later stage by the Board in support of its explanation.

it will thus be seen that though there was a change in the order in which charges were enumerated, the charges found proved were substantially the same as the charges levelled. We have already indicated that the seventh and eighth charges in the notice were really no charges and were mere inferences and that is why we find no mention of them in the notification.
We therefore allow the appeal, set aside the order of the High Court and dismiss the writ petition. In the circumstances we pass numberorders as to companyts.

edges.explanation: Holding that tentative conclusion keeps mind open grounds the concept
Holding on open mind addresses prejudgment issue

anchor.surface_text: Such tentative conclusion communicated to the Board does not mean that the State Government is not open to conviction at all and whatever the explanation it would pass an order in accordance with its tentative conclusion. There is therefore no reason to think that all proceedings subsequent to the issue of notice dated June 9, 1964 were in this case a farce.
We therefore allow the appeal, set aside the order of the High Court and dismiss the writ petition. In the circumstances we pass numberorders as to companyts.

We are of opinion that it is not correct to use the analogy of Art. 311 for the purpose of s. 298 of the Act. The issue of two notices under Art. 311 is a very special procedure depending upon the language of that Article. We find no comparable words in s. 298.
We therefore allow the appeal, set aside the order of the High Court and dismiss the writ petition. In the circumstances we pass numberorders as to companyts.
